text: We use natural gas to make everything from the polyester fibers in your clothing to the plastic in your cell phone to even components in your car engine and everything in between.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And so what happens is when you raise an input cost that is as ubiquitous as natural gas,
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: you are going to cause costs to go up throughout the economy.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And sure enough, that's what we've seen under this administration.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: These are the people that killed the Keystone XL pipeline literally on day one.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: From the beginning until all the way until today, they have been anti-energy.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: E.J., I know I said it was the last question.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: One more.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: I got two minutes left.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: There's a thing in economics you and I both know called the substitution effect.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: You know, price of chicken goes up, people buy more beef.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Price of beef goes up, they buy pork.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: You can substitute.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: You may not like it, but there's a way out of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: That's not the case with energy prices.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: What you just said is accurate.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: There's no way to avoid energy prices if you're going to restrict energy like the Biden administration with Harris are committed to.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: There's just no way.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: It's built into every single thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: That's right, Dan.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And that substitution effect, by the way, that happens not only at the local level, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It happens not only when the individual consumer is choosing, like you mentioned, what kind of meat do I want to buy?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: It happens at the international level as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: In other words, when we're not producing enough energy exports...
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Countries have to turn to sometimes hostile nations like Iran and buy energy from them.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: And so now, instead of money going to put Americans to work, you're putting money into the coffers of the warlords in Iran, and you're funding terrorism.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Right.

text: And it's just amazing how we're funding this war in Ukraine.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: Whatever your position is, I'm not even going to talk about that now.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: That's for another day.
speaker: SPEAKER_07

text: But we're funding a war in Ukraine while simultaneously restricting our own natural gas supply to allow others to buy natural gas to Russia.
